comment message: 70% is not the full variance. Many neurons in synergistic muscles are correlated with a unique subset of neurons. I strongly suggest you check with pearson correlation of the smoothed motor unit discharge rates. Also, force variability is only partly predicted by a single common input. Please stop assuming overly simplistic and reductionist conclusions.You also show that only 70% of the variance (which, in fact, should be 50 to 60% of the first component) is explained. In all other disciplines, it is usually concluded that it is only one component when it explains more than 90% of the variance! BOOK KNOWLEDGE: In Principal Component Analysis (PCA), when it's concluded that there is only one component, the first principal component should ideally explain a significant portion of the variance—typically more than 90%. However, the exact threshold can depend on the specific context or data, but generally, when a single component explains more than 90% of the variance, it's reasonable to conclude that this component captures the majority of the relevant information in the data. If the first component explains less than 90%, it might suggest that multiple components are needed to adequately represent the variance in the data, and assuming only one component could oversimplify the analysis. In your case, when discussing 70% variance, it might imply that the first component doesn't fully capture the structure of the data, and it could suggest that more components are necessary to explain a larger proportion of the variance.
paper title: A single low-dimensional neural component of motor unit activity explains force generation across repetitive isometric tasks
paper authors: Hélio V. Cabral, J. Greig Inglis, Elmira Pourreza, Milena A. Dos Santos, Caterina Cosentino, David O’Reilly, Ioannis Delis, Francesco Negro

comment message: I came through these data, which represents a novelty for me, endeavoured in the field of bioinformatics. The study by Chirumbolo et al. presents a compelling and innovative perspective on adaptive chaos and its role in modulating oxygen-ozone therapy for spine disorders. By integrating mathematical modeling, bioinformatics, and clinical insights, the authors provide a rigorous framework to understand how mild chaotic perturbations can enhance systemic complexity and biological resilience. A particular strength of this work lies in its multidimensional approach, incorporating Shannon entropy, Lyapunov exponents, and fractal dimensions to quantify the therapeutic impact of oxygen-ozone therapy. Therefire, in my opinion, the authors successfully demonstrate that low-dose ozone (20–40 µg/ml O3) fosters adaptive chaos, leading to reduced inflammation, enhanced repair, and improved systemic stability. In contrast, higher doses (>60 µg/ml O3) appear to push the system into pathological chaos, emphasizing the importance of precision dosing in regenerative medicine. Really interesting outcomes! The translational significance of this study cannot be overstated. It not only advances our understanding of chaos-driven medical interventions but also sets a precedent for personalized medicine strategies that leverage nonlinear dynamics to optimize therapeutic outcomes. Future research could expand on these findings by incorporating real-world clinical datasets and patient-specific modeling, further solidifying the role of adaptive chaos in medical practice. I trust this study is a landmark contribution to the fields of biophysics, complexity science, and regenerative medicine, offering novel insights into the interplay between biological chaos and therapeutic control. Great results!!
paper title: Harnessing Adaptive Chaos: Exploring the role of oxygen-ozone therapy in modulating complexity and repair in spine disorders via a bio-informatic model
paper authors: Salvatore Chirumbolo, Marianno Franzini, Umberto Tirelli, Giovanni Ricevuti, Fortunato Loprete, Tommaso Richelmi, Francesco Vaiano, Antonio Carlo Galoforo, Marianna Chierchia, Luigi Valdenassi

comment message: Dear Oscar, Thank you so much for your comments and feedback - it took a while to see this on this forum so apologies for the delayed response. We incorporated some of your suggestions to add more context to discoveries made by your group and others regarding Cav1 in Ewing Sarcoma- appreciate the suggestions! In our studies, the subset of CD99 High cells we characterized do indeed have caveolae- so in contrast to previous studies- we believe the signaling in these cells do depend on caveolae per se and not just Caveolin-1 expression. Thanks also for the comment on other signaling pathways- MAPK levels were low in our hands for all these cells (CD99 High or Low)  but maybe worth revisiting. Cheers, Dagan (first author)

comment message: Bold statement for a "superior" study that misrepresents the work of a similar study in their discussion paragraph 4 (Figueroa Velez et al. - me). First, the stimuli used by the authors here is static gratings vs drifting gratings. This alone should have made the discussion more nuanced than our paradigm is superior. While this study showed "more samples" per condition, the other study (mine) showed drifting gratings for 1.5s at 3Hz and so multiple samples per trial are shown (since phases are repeated in one showing). Drifting gratings have a motion component that leads to neuronal integration that could better pick up subtle differences in orientation selectivity. As for preferred spatial frequency, we both found that this was not perturbed. Yet, it should be noted that this "superior" study found the spatial frequency preferences were half those found in the inferior study (0.06 vs 0.12 cpd). In fact, their more coarse preferred spatial frequency values of adult V1 is more in line with our measurements in juvenile mice. Moreover, the way they carried out behavior (one screen grey, one with the same orientation but at varying spatial frequency) can only detect deficits in spatial acuity, which is is just one aspect determining visual acuity and is one that we both agree was not altered anyhow. Lastly, this "superior" study fails to show that they can measure immature responses as they never measured responses in juveniles. Given that their spatial frequency preferences match our juvenile values, the validity of their bold title is brought into question. The inferior study also had inhibitory neuron responses gathered in parallel, thus showing that a range of visual tuning properties can be measured by the inferior study authors. But sure, go ahead and discuss science as black and white rather than have a more nuanced discussion.

comment message: As representatives of PreOmics, we would like to highlight a key observation in the submitted manuscript for readers to consider. Supplementary Figure 1: The authors describe the injection of 300 ng peptides, but Supplementary Figure 1 shows variations in TIC signal intensities for the compared techniques. These differences may stem from the two different peptide quantification assays employed and described in the study. From a mass spectrometry perspective, such discrepancies make it challenging to technically compare different enrichment techniques due to the influence of signal intensity variations on the S/N ratio, peak-picking algorithms, peptide quantities, and sequence coverage. We recommend to repeat the study and use our recommendations for peptide quantification compatible to ENRICHplus. In addition, it is important to acknowledge that the ENRICHplus pre-release version was employed for the comparison, which differs from the commercial version scheduled for release on February 22, 2025. PreOmics is always supportive if customers struggle to achieve expected results with our solutions and we are keen to support you and provide our recommendations to achieve the best results possible.
paper title: A Technical Evaluation of Plasma Proteomics Technologies
paper authors: William F. Beimers, Katherine A. Overmyer, Pavel Sinitcyn, Noah M. Lancaster, Scott T. Quarmby, Joshua J. Coon

comment message: This is a very interesting work, however the by using of the GHK current equation the results cannot be uniquely interpreted as due to the creation of a calcium channel. As an example a channel in which Calcium acts as an activator would produce the same apparent effects. In order to really show that this is a Calcium channel the authors would need to show that there are no changes in the open probability in the different conditions. That's why in the field the GHK voltage equation with bi-ionic potentials is used. Where the authors not able to measure bi-ionic potentials by putting sodium or magnesium in their intracellular solution?

comment message: It's a remarkable achievement to go from virtual screening to subnanomolar affinity and bound structures in one paper. On a minor point, I would recommend adding "neutral" to phrases such as "antagonists and inverse agonists", and in the title. The present wording could be taken to imply two separate categories, but almost all antagonists are inverse agonists. For instance, naloxone and JDTic are indeed antagonists as noted here, but both are also inverse agonists.

comment message: Hi Karin, thanks for your comment. While we did observe a MOR induced non-canonical potentiation of glutamate transmission at the MHb-IPN synapse, MOR activation also directly inhibited MHb and IPN cell activity. Therefore, it is not clear how MOR activation affects the overall output of the MHb-IPN pathway and if this would influence respiratory activity through downstream structures. Though it is an interesting hypothesis. Best, Sarthak Singhal.

comment message: Thank you for your response, which largely mirrors our findings but presents alternative interpretations. Our analysis suggests that the observed Sendai virus RNA results are due to Sendai virus persistence or contamination in specific cell lines, rather than errors during RNA-seq library preparation. Evidence of Historical Contamination: Sendai virus sequences were identified in control human ESCs from Buckberry et al.’s study, where no intentional infection was performed. This pattern of contamination recurs in another independent study from the Polo lab (Liu et al., Nature Methods 2017), indicating a long-standing issue with cell line handling rather than repetitive incidental contamination during library preparations (Figure 1b). Selective Detection of Sendai Virus RNA: We observed a gradient in Sendai virus expression across different time-course samples and cell culture conditions (Figure 1b). Only uninfected fibroblasts and TNT iPSCs were completely Sendai-free. This gradient, along with the presence of Sendai-free samples, supports the notion that Sendai virus detection is associated with specific cell lines, not random library preparation errors. Noncompliance with Manufacturer’s Protocols: The CytoTune™ 2.0 Reprogramming Kit Manual explicitly instructs picking iPSC colonies and following steps for Sendai virus removal—steps that were not adhered to by Buckberry et al. Disregarding these crucial instructions has compromised the studied iPSCs, raising concerns about the reliability and reproducibility of the obtained results. Additionally, the response states: "The potential continued expression of the Sendai virus in Naive-hiPS cells has already been reported by us and others in the field [3–5]." However, neither the Nature nor the Nature Methods papers discuss Sendai expression in naive samples, nor do they cite the study by Yamanaka's lab that addresses this issue.
paper title: Sendai virus persistence questions the transient naive reprogramming method for iPSC generation
paper authors: Alejandro De Los Angeles, Clemens B. Hug, Vadim N. Gladyshev, George M. Church, Sergiy Velychko

comment message: Hi Eric, sorry for the late reply. It seems like DoRothEA ( https://saezlab.github.io/dorothea/) is a GRN inference tool. We used SCENIC in our method. One can use DoRothEA or other tools to get the network and run the algorithm on that. DoRothEA gives negative edge weights too, so it might be interesting. Thank you again for your interest. -Zarzees
paper title: GAGER: gene regulatory network assisted gene expression restoration
paper authors: Md Zarzees Uddin Shah Chowdhury, Sumaiya Sultana Any, Md. Abul Hasan Samee, Atif Rahman
